Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 15 hours. The homework takes a lot of time and need rigorous background literature search.

1
One homework requires you to re do the entire statistical methods section on SAS for a paper. The data is provided. This assignment took me and my fellow students around 10 hours to complete.
Three hours
1 hour
several papers reading and one assignment

It varied tremendously- some weeks there was no homework, so I spent about 1-2 hours on readings. For homeworks 1 and 2 these took about 4 hours each. Homework 3 required 10-15 hours work. In the final weeks, I spent 5-8 hours a week (for about 4 weeks) working on the final project.
I spent roughly 6 hours per week on weekly readings and homework assignments. For the final presentation and paper I spent 20 hours total in preparation and writing.
Depends on the week, mostly around 3-5 hours a week but the biostats hw assignment week took me about 30 hours.
The only times I spent time on this course was for homework assignments (maybe 3 hours each). And then a few hours on the final assignments. Other than that I spent no time preparing for this course.
Averaged over the entire semester, I spent ~2-3 hours per week on the course. However, that was an average where some weeks I spent 0 hours and other weeks I spent >16 hours.
6 hours
3 hours
6 hours per week

I feel that the course would be better marketed as "topics in environmental epidemiology" or as a seminar. Perhaps framing it as detailed case studies of different types of environmental epidemiology methods would be more accurate. It would have been interesting to hear about more research outside of the instructor's.

This course was very poor. The topics were not incredibly interesting, and the lecture format was not exciting. The homework assignments were given without guidance, and they were graded quite critically.

The course was a good introduction to EHS Epidemiology topics, but is somewhat redundant for EHS students. The assignments were reasonable, but an assignment that involves statistical analysis should be prefaced by some lecture that refreshes the statistical analysis expectations.
Not all deadlines are on syllabus. Homework 3 was too hard and out of scope for the class. She did not teach us anything from the third assignment.
Students can utilize the knowledge in biostatistics and epi they have learned in first year to conduct their thesis work on this class, and the workload of  this class is not too heavy.

Non-interactive. 
Student involvement is almost non-existent.

Strengths: a good course to apply the epi knowledge in case studies

weaknesses: could introduce more cases extensively from other research fields

I am not sure what the learning objective of this course was. I was hoping to learn more specific epidemiological skills, with specific applications to environmental health questions- however, I do not think I learned this at all. The lectures did not seem to have clear learning goals and were primarily the professor talking about her own research (which was interesting, but was not what I thought the course was designed for). The third homework, which involved recreating a published statistical analysis using SAS, was completely a surprise considering we never did any of this in class. Additionally, we did even receive any feedback on this assignment (which many students found very challenging) until after the last day of class. Although the final project (writing a grant proposal and designing a study) was interesting, I did not think we learned much in the course that was actually relevant to this project. Overall, I think the course could be improved by having more concrete learning objectives and better aligning what is taught in lecture with the assignments.
The topics are interesting, but the way they are presented is not. Also, it would be best to have classes recorded for students who have to occasionally miss class.

Almost no classroom participation or student engagement. Just a two hour lecture. Homework was poorly constructed and poorly graded. Slow grading. 
Within the first 20 minutes, every student in class is doing other work on their laptops.

The course is of the type where you get out of it what you put in. You could easily cruise through the semester and pass, but not learn much. If you put in time and effort to master the homework assignments (critique and analysis of studies), and take your research proposal as far as possible, you will have a covered quite a bit of ground. The TA Huang Huang and Dr. Zhang are both very helpful and make themselves available as needed throughout the semester. For some students, the course might be too open-ended and seem to lack high-definition guidelines, but this style of teaching also encourages students to be as thorough and analytical as possible, and forces students to ask questions when things are unclear.

I did not enjoy this class. I felt like I did not learn any epidemiology and was in a glorified journal club. Additionally, some of the hw assignment were unfair; some students had taken AAME which taught them how to do the hw and similar analyses in SAS however many of us did not take this course and were never taught how to do the assignment. There were limited office hours and help to complete the assignment and we were never taught how to do it in class even after voicing this. Afterwards, the assignment was not curved to take into account that some students were never taught how to do the analyses and struggled for many hours on our own. I think the hw is appropriate in theory if we were taught the material. Overall, I wish I was taught more concrete things.
This course was an absolutely waste of money. I learned absolutely nothing. The instruction was utterly un-engaging and uninspiring.

The class is focused on critically analyzing scientific data through the review of scientific studies. This was an effective method and I really appreciated the opportunity to learn more about the methods used in study design.

The course was too focused on the instructor's research, and didn't have enough breadth. 

Strengths: Case studies, research papers

Weaknesses: Duplication of material, too focused on instructor's field of research.
I think what I learned from this course is very useful in future research.

The class feels like a REVIEW of intro to epidemiology. The class did not introduce any new concepts regarding epidemiology. The lectures and homework are heavily based on the projects/papers done by the instructor. She walks through them during each lecture. She occasionally brings in guest speakers. The syllabus does not specify the due date of the homework, and some other deadlines, so it's hard to keep track of the class progress. The homework are usually assigned a week before due date, and ask you to summarize the assigned paper.
The homeworks, for the most part, were manageable, but the last one was out of the scope of the class and not congruent with what we were learning.
Very knowledgeable and helpful.
Dr. Zhang could organize the course much better - There were a few class times that we were dismissed because nothing was prepared.
Yawei is extremely knowledgeable and experienced, but the course topics and discussion could be somewhat redundant.

Speaks off tangent too much
Lectures not always related to what she says
Yawei is responsible and patient, she asked us to communicate with her in terms of thesis work, including topic selection, progress etc. In the same term, she gave us a plenty of feedbacks.
Class was monotonous.
She is nice and kind.

Dr. Zhang is very nice and provides opportunities for students to work directly with her. She obviously has interest and expertise in this subject area. However, her lectures primarily focused on her specific research projects and it was not clear what students should be taking away/learning from this. I think she could improve her teaching by restructuring this course and providing very specific learning goals. She should teach specific skills that could be applied to many areas of environmental epidemiology, not just her specific studies.
good

Need to stimulate way more classroom participation. Forcing people to sign-in for attendance will not make students participate. The professor needs to engage students in class to stimulate discussions.

Dr. Zhang is an excellent instructor. She was a great resource with regard to my questions about study design and analysis, and helped me address some issues around tissue sampling sites to look for DNA-methylation. Dr. Zhang was also very supportive throughout the semester.
This course needs to be taught by someone who actually enjoys teaching.
Dr. Zhang was incredibly knowledgeable about her subject and study designs. It was a great experience to learn about study designs from someone with extensive experience in the field.
Clear, but could do a better job at entertaining student suggestions and inquiries.
Great and very patient.
The instructor is nice in person. She meets with the groups for final projects, and offers timely and helpful feedbacks. She is open to questions and suggestions.
I would recommend it to someone looking for an introduction to methods used in environmental epidemiology.
Be sure to learn well using SAS or R.
I would not recommend this course.
This course is a good introduction to EHS epidemiology topics, but it is somewhat redundant for students who have epidemiology or EHS backgrounds.
Do not recommend. Waste of time.
It is an appropriate course to further understand the application of epi study.

This course is interesting if you want to learn about a few examples of environmental epidemiology studies, primarily those done as part of the professor's own research. However, if you want to learn concrete epidemiological skills this course is not particularly relevant. Although having knowledge of epi I and biostats is useful in the course, this course does not particularly extend or solidify the knowledge that you get in those classes.
recommend
Not good.
I would recommend this course with the caveat that you need to be thorough with each assignment, and that there is maybe more self-learning involved in this course than others.
I would not recommend this class. I would recommend taking epidemiology 2 instead so that they can learn epidemiology, I wish I had.
Only take it if you have to. Otherwise, don't waste the money or time.
I would strongly recommend this course to any student who is think about designing a study and would like feedback from experienced professionals.
Would not recommend this course. Seemed like more of a "special topics" course than a general environmental epidemiology course.
Yes. Very useful for future research

It is required for EHS students, and would be a good class for anyone wish to fill the EHS requirement. The workload is relatively small. But remember, it is not an alternative of epi 2. If you wish to learn more, this is not the class you want.
